summary: Lyndon B. Johnson is mentioned in these documents primarily in the context of his succession to the presidency following John F. Kennedy's assassination. Many documents consist of messages of condolence sent to Johnson from various world leaders and organizations. Several reports analyze the likely foreign and domestic policy shifts under the Johnson administration. Some documents discuss meetings and briefings Johnson received on sensitive intelligence matters, including covert operations related to Cuba and Vietnam. There are also references to his awareness of potential plans to assassinate Fidel Castro. Later documents refer to the LBJ Library and its holdings related to Cuba, indicating ongoing interest in his administration's policies.
significance: Lyndon B. Johnson's significance in the JFK assassination context stems from his immediate succession to the presidency. The documents reflect the immediate aftermath of the assassination, including global reactions, concerns about policy continuity, and intelligence briefings provided to the new president. Some documents also suggest a potential awareness of covert operations and assassination plots, raising questions about the extent of his knowledge and involvement in such activities.
